awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Novel Microlocal-Analysis and Domain-Decomposition Based Fast Algorithms for Elastic Wave Modeling and Inversion in Variable Media
awd_abstract_narration:
Wave propagation is an important phenomenon in many science and engineering disciplines. Computational wave propagation has become a fundamental, vigorously growing technology in diverse disciplines, ranging from radar, sonar, seismic imaging, medical imaging, submarine detection, stealth technology, remote sensing and electronics to microscopy and nanotechnology. These applications are important in particular for the petroleum industry, medical imaging, and material sciences. One of the most challenging problems in computational wave propagation is how to carry out large-scale high frequency wave propagation efficiently and accurately. The investigators in this project will develop novel, fast algorithms for high frequency elastic wave propagation and inversion. In particular, they will focus on techniques including microlocal-analysis and domain-decomposition based fast Huygens sweeping methods and fast multiscale Gaussian beam methods to tackle this long-standing challenge.  Graduate students will be involved and receive interdisciplinary training. 

The project is motivated by science and engineering applications, and it will foster innovations in several theoretical and computational aspects. The goal is to develop efficient and accurate Hadamard-Babich expansion based fast Huygens sweeping methods and multiscale Gaussian wavepacket transform based fast multiscale Gaussian beams for elastic wave propagation in variable media in the high frequency regime and in the presence of caustics. Several avenues of research will be pusrued. First, the proposed new methods will address the challenges in large-scale high-frequency elastic wave modeling and inversion in the presence of caustics. Second, advances will be made in developing novel Hadamard-Babich expansion, domain decomposition, and butterfly-algorithm based fast Huygens sweeping methods for partial differential equation-based Eulerian geometrical optics and computational wave propagation. Both the Hadamard-Babich expansion and domain-decomposition based fast Huygens sweeping method and the fast multiscale Gaussian beam method are capable of producing uniform asymptotic solutions beyond caustics for wave propagation in the high-frequency regime. Third, the new methods will provide efficient tools not used before for many elastic wave-related applications in inhomogeneous media, such as seismic imaging and inversion, and medical imaging and inversion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_street_address: 323 DR MARTIN LUTHER KING JR BLVD

por.por_cntn:
This grant developed  advanced numerical methods for acoustic/electromagnetic wave propagation problems in complex structures.
The numerical methods that were developed have  contributed to advancing industrial applications such as microchip design, stealth technology,
radar, remote sensing, and many others. Some of these  methods can be extended to other areas in science and technology such as those related to porous media flow and to fully nonlinear elliptic equations.
Fundamental theoretical and computational problems in the design of high-frequency integral equations and efficient iterative solvers were addressed.   
The research activities conducted in this project represent an important contribution in  the field of high frequency hybrid numerical-asymptotic methods,
which greatly aid applied  mathematicians and engineers in simulating challenging problems proposed in industry and academia. 
Significant progress has been made toward the challenging design of quasi-independent high frequency numerical solvers for multiple scattering.
To this end,  critical mathematical analysis of the asymptotic expansions based on integral equations and pseudo-differential techniques were conducted in tandem with code development to validate the obtained algorithms.  In addition, an efficient innovative non-overlapping domain decomposition method was designed. This significantly enhances the convergence of the related iteration by introducing a new approach to the treatment of the continuity conditions in the neighborhood  of the so called cross points.  The success of these numerical algorithms will have a positive impact on projects of the PI’s colleagues, in NJIT and elsewhere, which are concerned with the design of numerical methods based on integral equations and finite element methods.  Two PhD students were trained in state-of-the-art numerical methods for scattering and wave propagation problems. The obtained results were disseminated through publications and conference presentations in  various  meetings. 


Last Modified: 09/13/2024
Modified by: Yassine Boubendir
por.por_txt_cntn:
This grant developed advanced numerical methods for acoustic/electromagnetic wave propagation problems in complex structures.
The numerical methods that were developed have contributed to advancing industrial applications such as microchip design, stealth technology,
radar, remote sensing, and many others. Some of these methods can be extended to other areas in science and technology such as those related to porous media flow and to fully nonlinear elliptic equations.


Fundamental theoretical and computational problems in the design of high-frequency integral equations and efficient iterative solvers were addressed. 
The research activities conducted in this project represent an important contribution in the field of high frequency hybrid numerical-asymptotic methods,
which greatly aid applied mathematicians and engineers in simulating challenging problems proposed in industry and academia.
Significant progress has been made toward the challenging design of quasi-independent high frequency numerical solvers for multiple scattering.
To this end, critical mathematical analysis of the asymptotic expansions based on integral equations and pseudo-differential techniques were conducted in tandem with code development to validate the obtained algorithms. In addition, an efficient innovative non-overlapping domain decomposition method was designed. This significantly enhances the convergence of the related iteration by introducing a new approach to the treatment of the continuity conditions in the neighborhood of the so called cross points. The success of these numerical algorithms will have a positive impact on projects of the PIs colleagues, in NJIT and elsewhere, which are concerned with the design of numerical methods based on integral equations and finite element methods. Two PhD students were trained in state-of-the-art numerical methods for scattering and wave propagation problems. The obtained results were disseminated through publications and conference presentations in various meetings.
